Award.AwardTitle: ABI Development: Dryad: scalable and sustainable infrastructure for the publication of data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Duke University, in collaboration with North Carolina State University and University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, is awarded a grant to enhance the services provided by Dryad (http://datadryad.org), a recently launched repository for data underlying the findings in the scholarly bioscience literature. Dryad is distinguished by the close association of data deposition with the process and business of scholarly publishing, and by using article publication as a model for how researchers can benefit from data sharing infrastructure. In a short time, dozens of journals have adopted Dryad as a mechanism for data archiving, and the repository is now at a point of transition to a sustainable organization that has the capacity to make thousands of new datasets each year openly available for reuse in perpetuity. Technical and organizational innovations supported by this award will enhance the Dryad's scalability and sustainability. The technical goals include: automation of metadata curation and preservation tasks; developing more efficient and scalable processes to integrate the manuscript submission processes of journals with the data submission process of Dryad; enhancing the features and usability of the deposition interface; and improving the machine and human interfaces for filtering, searching and accessing repository contents. Dryad?s business model will be refined through evaluation of the costs and benefits of data archiving and data reuse to stakeholders, and continued evaluation of Dryad's role with respect to the many emergent technologies in the world of publishing and data repositories. Dryad's sustainability will be addressed by implementing a nonprofit governance and revenue model that has been developed over the past three years by diverse stakeholders in the research, publishing, library and funder communities.

The Broader Impacts of Dryad stem from its potential to transform the way research data are communicated and preserved. The credibility and effectiveness of the research enterprise is due in large part to the social contract behind scholarly publishing. Researchers are incentivized to disclose their work to their peers in return for professional credit. In so doing, they also expose their findings to be confirmed or refuted, and enable other researchers to build upon their results. Dryad seeks to extend this social contract to research data by providing a model for how a disciplinary repository can incentivize researchers to disclose the data that is of the greatest value for scientific reuse, that associated with publications, and realize the manifold benefits of free access to scientific data in perpetuity. This award will provide resources for Dryad to to reach out to the next generation of researchers through educational initiatives and partnerships with the broader community. As new journal and funder mandates raise demand and expectations for data management, preservation, and dissemination services, Dryad - as a stable, community-governed organization - aims to be in a position to provide the necessary infrastructure, as well as provide a focused forum for participating journals, societies and publishers to take coordinated, and well-informed, steps toward improved policy and practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists generate large amounts and many kinds of data in the course of their research endeavors, and these data are increasingly being recognized as valuable products of the research enterprise. The discoverability and accessibility of research data are critical for promoting research transparency and ensuring the validity of research results. The Dryad Digital Repository was launched in 2008 to address the needs of the life sciences community for an easy-to-use, general purpose repository where data underlying scientific publications could be easily discovered, freely reusable, and citable.  

The Intellectual Merit of this project is through enabling the organization managing the repository, Dryad, to scale up its technical infrastructure to support the rapidly expanding user base of journals and researchers, to ensure that the repository is meeting the needs of that user base, and to undergo a transition to a financially independent not-for-profit organization. Specific technical goals included continued automation of metadata curation and preservation tasks; developing more efficient and scalable processes to integrate the manuscript submission processes of journals with the data submission process of Dryad; enhancing the features and usability of the deposition interface; and improving the machine and human interfaces for filtering, searching and accessing repository contents.  Specific organizational goals included development of Dryad’s not-for-profit business model and its structure of community governance. 

The Broader Impacts of the project include aiming to improve the effectiveness, credibility and durability of life science research through a dramatic increase in the availability of research data associated with published work in the field. These impacts are magnified through the journals, societies and publishers that partner with Dryad to integrate manuscript and data submission, to require data archiving as a condition for publication, and promote best practices in data archiving to their research communities. Dryad also promotes culture change towards open data in the next generation of researchers through a educational initiatives that enable learning with authentic research data.

During the lifetime of the project, from 2012 through the end of 2016, the number of journals that integrated manuscript and data submission grew over four-fold while the number of data packages held by the repository grew approximately eight-fold.  These data packages are associated with over 600 different journals, books, theses and dissertations and have over 60,000 different authors. Usage has grown dramatically from about 28,000 data file downloads in 2012 to over 475,000 in 2016. Numerous technical and workflow improvements have enabled the repository to handle the increased data curation load and repository usage, including improved automation of metadata curation and preservation tasks; improved processes for integrating the manuscript submission processes of journals with the data submission process of Dryad, including the development of processes to allow confidential peer review of data prior to its public release, development of an API for automated manuscript submission integration with large journals; enhancements to the usability of the repository website and submission interface; and improvements to the discoverability of repository contents, including incorporation of ORCIDs for identity control of author names.

During the course of the project, the Dryad organization developed its membership-based governance model, received 501(c)3 not-for-profit status and introduced a revenue model that is currently providing the majority of funds for daily operations. In this model, revenues are provided through Data Publication Charges associated with individual data packages, paid by a diversity of sponsors, including scientific societies, publishers, institutional libraries, and individual researchers.

As part of a supplement to this project, Dryad investigated the feasibility of direct sponsorship from a funder, conducted a survey of depositors to study how researchers are paying individual DPCs (including the relationship of those costs to active awards and prior Data Management Plans) and conducted interviews with stakeholders to guage changing attitudes toward paying for the archiving of published research data.

The project has provided digital curation training for numerous information and library science undergraduate and graduate students, and supported the development and deployment of educational materials for learning science through the use of authentic data in community college and university classrooms. The work has been disseminated through seven peer-reviewed publications and dozens of conferences, workshops and journal business meetings presentations, as well as through a robust social media presence.
